docs.abstract: Does it make sense when your audience is too young to comprehend language at all?
docs.snippet: Does it make sense when your audience is too young to comprehend language at all?
docs.lead_paragraph: Kara writes: My husband and I have been reading “The Fellowship of the Ring” to our infant daughter before bed. We know she isn’t getting anything from the story yet, but reading aloud has many benefits for her development, and it’s fun for us. However, when my husband reads, he likes to do fun voices and sing the songs. I feel like a buzz kill, but I just want to hear the story!

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on Using Funny Voices While Reading
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman

docs.abstract: In a moving interview, Bryan, who has spent 31 years in a Texas prison for the 1985 murder of his wife, talks about his life behind bars and trying to keep hope alive.
docs.snippet: In a moving interview, Bryan, who has spent 31 years in a Texas prison for the 1985 murder of his wife, talks about his life behind bars and trying to keep hope alive.
docs.lead_paragraph: This summer and fall, as Joe Bryan’s attorneys argued that he deserved a new trial, Bryan watched in silence. Although he was at the center of the evidentiary hearing in Comanche, Texas, he was never afforded a chance to speak. Dressed in a black-and-white-striped jail jumpsuit, he sat beside his defense attorneys, listening intently to each witness, a finger usually pressed to his temple in concentration. I often wondered what he was thinking.

headline.main: Joe Bryan in His Own Words: On Being Convicted With Expert Testimony That Turned Out to Be Wrong

docs.abstract: At a time when the British royals have never seemed more anachronistic, Peter Morgan has shown viewers why it isn’t easy being queen.
docs.snippet: At a time when the British royals have never seemed more anachronistic, Peter Morgan has shown viewers why it isn’t easy being queen.
docs.lead_paragraph: Toward the end of 2015, Peter Morgan, the British dramatist and screenwriter, received a small brown envelope in the mail. It looked like a speeding ticket, or a letter from the Inland Revenue, and as he tore it open he felt the first throb of a mild bureaucratic headache. As it happened, the British state was singling him out for different purposes. Morgan had been named in Queen Elizabeth II’s annual New Year Honors list for his “services to drama.” Henceforth, he would be a Commander of the Order of the British Empire, or, Peter Morgan, C.B.E. His presence was requested at Buckingham Palace for the investiture ceremony.

headline.main: How the Man Behind ‘The Crown’ Made the Monarchy Relevant Again

keywords.name: persons

docs.abstract: There’s really no need for leafy greens in this big, varied and meaty salad.
docs.snippet: There’s really no need for leafy greens in this big, varied and meaty salad.
docs.lead_paragraph: For a while, my job was to make French fries at a restaurant in Fairfax County, Va. I did nothing else. I peeled big potatoes and dropped them in water, my hands slippery with starch. When I had enough potatoes, I carried them to the ancient fry-cutting machine, a cast-iron relic of the 1960s, and, putting the weight of my entire body on the lever to bring it down, I crushed them one at a time. In went a potato, out came a dozen or so perfectly thick batons with sharp, square edges. I deep-fried the pieces, then spread them out, floppy and pale, in a single layer on a sheet pan and tucked them back in the fridge. When someone ordered fries, I cooked the pieces again. Finally, finally, the outside got brown and crisp, the insides tender, like mashed potatoes. While they were hot, I tossed the fries with salt, and sometimes they were perfect.

headline.main: A Simple Citrus Salad to Brighten Up the Dead of Winter
